DOC.TEXT: Robert Pirosh, whose 1949 screenplay ``Battleground'' won an Academy Award and who co-wrote the Marx Brothers' classic ``A Day at the Races,'' died Monday of heart failure. He was 79. Priosh, who wrote, produced or directed a dozen well-known films and a similar number of television series, remained active through his later years, most recently teaching writing at the University of Southern California. His 1949 Oscar-winning drama was based on the fighting between German and Allied troops at the Battle of the Bulge, where he fought with the 320th Infantry in the 35th Division at Bastogne, Belgium. He was writer or co-writer of the films ``A Day at the Races''; ``I Married a Witch''; ``Hell Is for Heroes''; ``A Gathering of Eagles''; ``What's So Bad About Feeling Good?''; ``Go for Broke,'' and many more. As a TV writer, he wrote the pilot programs for ``Laramie'' and ``Combat.'' He also wrote segments of ``Hawaii Five-O,'' ``Ellery Queen,'' ``Mannix,'' ``Bonanza,'' ``Ironside,'' ``The Waltons'' and ``Barnaby Jones,'' among others.

J. Willcox Dunn, a retired newspaper editor and publisher who crusaded against gambling, died Friday. He was 91. Dunn, a native of Suffolk, in 1952, established the weekly Princess Anne Free Press, serving Virginia Beach and Princess Anne County. He was its editor, publisher and sole owner until he ceased its publication on retiring in 1962. In 1958, Dunn was awarded the national Elijah Parish Lovejoy Award for Courage in Journalism for his opposition to political corruption and racketeering in the region. He received his law degree from the University of Virginia in 1922. He practiced law in Lynchburg and worked for Union Carbide in New York City before moving to Virginia Beach in 1936, where he entered the real estate business. In 1935 he married Lelia Baker Taylor of Norfolk. His wife died in 1962. Survivors include a daughter, Margaret T. Dunn of Charlottesville; a son, Joseph W. Dunn Jr. of Virginia Beach; two sisters, Mary D. Wallace of Richmond and Martha D. Lyon of Warren, Mich.; and three grandchildren.

Thomas Harold ``Hal'' Cunningham, the retired editor and publisher of the Llano News and a former president of the Texas Press Association, died Saturday of cardiac arrest. He was 81. A native of Henrietta, Texas, he earned his bachelor's and master's degrees in journalism at the University of Texas in Austin. After managing Camp LaJunta in Hunt, Texas, in the late 1940s and early '50s, Cunningham in 1954 became news editor of the Kerrville Mountain Sun, a post he held for five years before purchasing the Llano News, a weekly which he published for 25 years. He retired in 1983. Cunningham served as president of the state Texas Press Association from 1982-83. Cunningham is survived by his wife, Hazel Cunningham of Llano, and a nephew.

Actress Madoline Thomas, a veteran of the National Theater and the Royal Shakespeare Company, died Saturday, three days before her 100th birthday. Miss Thomas had been in a hospital in Weston-super-Mare, on England's west coast, for more than a week after breaking her hip in a fall at the nursing home where she had lived for three years, the British news agency said. Born in Abergavenny, South Wales, Miss Thomas spent six seasons with the Royal Shakespeare Company at Stratford-on-Avon, notably in ``Wars of the Roses,'' and five years at the National. In 1982, when she was 92, she appeared in National's ``Uncle Vanya,'' directed by Sir Peter Hall. Her West End appearances included ``The Mousetrap'' and ``Three Sisters.''
